This grand seven-terraced palace sits atop the Zabarwan Mountain range and offers breathtaking views of Dal Lake and the surrounding mountains. Built in the 17th century by Dara Shikoh, it is a perfect blend of Islamic and Persian architecture.Visited Pari Mahal, a protected monument in Kashmir, during May 2024. Pari Mahal, which translates to "Abode Of Fairies" is a seven-terraced garden located atop the Zabarwan mountain range. This location offers tourists a stunning view of Srinagar and Dal Lake. It is said to have been developed by Dara Shikoh, showcasing exquisite Islamic architecture. Tickets can be purchased from the counter near the entrance gate. The beautifully preserved and decorated gardens of all seven terraces are sure to leave a lasting impression on tourists. The structures are remarkable to see, as they historically served as a library, an observatory for astrology and astronomy, and a place of residence. The site has neat and clean washrooms. Wheelchair access is doubtful and should be checked with the authorities. Parking is available in front of the main entrance. Overall, it is a lovely terraced garden well worth visiting. Great job by Archeological Survey Of India.Navin S ‚Äî Google reviewPari Mahal, located in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir, India, is a historic palace built in the 17th century by Dara Shikoh, the Mughal prince and brother of Aurangzeb. This beautiful seven-terraced garden palace was originally designed as a school of astrology and offered stunning views of the surrounding landscape. Pari Mahal is a testament to Mughal architecture and is known for its intricate design, beautiful gardens, and tranquil atmosphere. Pari Mahal is a must-visit destination in Srinagar, offering breathtaking views of the surrounding mountains and valleys. The palace's architecture and gardens are a testament to the region's rich history. One of the highlights of visiting Pari Mahal is the cleanliness of its restrooms, which is a welcome amenity for tourists. The views from the palace are stunning, with the majestic mountains serving as a backdrop. While the steep steps to the palace can be challenging, the scenic views and historical significance make it well worth the effort. Additionally, the ticket prices are very reasonable, making it an accessible destination for all. Overall, Pari Mahal is a great place to visit, offering a mix of history, natural beauty, and convenience.Sia ‚Äî Google reviewPari Mahal ‚Äì A Stunning Viewpoint! Various tour packages offer hassle-free booking of accommodations in Srinagar hotels, ensuring a comfortable and memorable stay. The floating gardens, vibrant houseboats, and local vendors selling snacks and souvenirs from their boats add a unique charm to the whole experience. It is the largest of the three stunning Mughal Gardens in Srinagar, built by Emperor Jahangir in 1619 for his wife Noor Jahan. The garden offers breathtaking views of Dal Lake and showcases exquisite Mughal horticultural craftsmanship.Shalimar Garden in Kashmir is a very pretty garden made a long time ago by Mughal emperors. It is also called "the place of love." Emperor Jahangir built it first in 1619, and later his wife, Nur Jahan, made it bigger. Visited this amazing place in May 2024. The garden looks amazing with three flat grassy areas and a long stream of water going down the middle. There are also lots of green plants everywhere. Inside, there are two old important buildings. One is called Diwan-e-Aam, where regular people used to meet the emperor. The other is Diwan-e-Khas, for private meetings. The buildings were under renovation then. Lots of people like taking pictures there. The garden feels magical and makes everybody happy. Kids of all ages enjoy coming to this garden. You need to buy tickets to go inside the garden. You can park your car there, and there are also parking spots on the street outside. Near the garden, there are many small shops selling things like quick food, ice cream, cold drinks, and snacks. It is a place you should definitely visit if you go to Kashmir.Navin S ‚Äî Google reviewGood place for kids and family to kill atleast 2 hours. The greeny lawn is maintained properly. Encompassing an expansive 200-acre area, it features four distinct sections: Recreational Garden, Botanical Garden, Plant Introduction Center, and Research Section.I was fortunate enough to visit the Jawaharlal Nehru Botanical Garden in Srinagar in February, 2025 and must say that it exceeded my expectations. The botanical garden was set up in 1969 and fully established in 1987 in memory of India's first Prime Minister. The garden has a collection of about 150,000 ornamental plants and a huge collection of oak varieties with a lake that spreads over 17 hectares. Admission is 30rs for adults and 100rs for foreigners. Nestled amidst the stunning Zabarwan Mountain range, this three-terraced garden showcases Persian-influenced architecture and features natural spring water flowing through its landscaped terraces.Beautiful garden with many different varieties of plants facing Dal lake and snow capped mountains in the background. Famous for its natural minerals rich water spring, that has been long used for ages by many. Although the water pressure has gone quite low now, but do drink it and carry some along. Also a beautiful soothing garden here.Manik S ‚Äî Google reviewChashme Shahi, also known as the Royal Spring, is one of the most beautiful and serene Mughal gardens in Srinagar, Kashmir. Built in 1632 by Ali Mardan Khan under the orders of Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan for his son Dara Shikoh, this charming garden is the smallest among the three famous Mughal gardens in Srinagar, but it holds immense historical and natural beauty. The garden is built around a natural spring that was discovered by Rupa Bhawani, a revered Kashmiri saint, and is believed to have medicinal properties. Many visitors even bring bottles to take some of the spring water home. The layout of Chashme Shahi follows the traditional Mughal garden style with three terraced levels, each adorned with well-maintained flowerbeds, flowing water channels, and small fountains that create a soothing, musical ambiance. What makes this garden unique is the natural spring that flows through each level, adding to its charm and peaceful environment. Set against the backdrop of the Zabarwan mountains and overlooking the shimmering Dal Lake, the views from Chashme Shahi are absolutely breathtaking. During spring and early summer, the garden bursts into a riot of colors with blooming tulips, roses, and other flowers, making it a paradise for nature lovers and photographers. It‚Äôs a great place for a relaxing walk, a quiet picnic, or just some moments of peace amidst nature. The entry fee is minimal, and the garden is open from March to November, usually from 9:30 AM to 5:30 PM. Easily accessible from Srinagar city, it‚Äôs located near the Raj Bhawan and is often included in day tours along with Nishat and Shalimar Bagh. Overall, Chashme Shahi is a must-visit destination that offers beauty, history, and tranquility in one perfect package.Chandan S ‚Äî Google reviewWe visited during afternoon. There was not much rush. Chashma Shahi, also known as the "Royal Spring," is one of the most beautiful and historically rich Mughal gardens in Srinagar, Kashmir. This charming terraced garden offers a blend of natural beauty, Persian architecture, and cultural heritage. The highlight of Chashma Shahi is its fresh water spring, believed to have medicinal properties. I heard,¬† Pandit Jaharlal Neheru used to drink this water. The water flows gracefully through the garden's terraced layout, adding a soothing charm to the atmosphere. This garden was well maintained¬† and refreshing. You have to came here by toto or auto from Tulip Garden. Entry ticket Rs. 30 for adult and Rs. 15 for child.Siddhartha D ‚Äî Google reviewVisited the beautiful Chasme Shahi Garden in Kashmir during May 2024 after buying tickets at the entrance. This Mughal garden has an Iranian design and is built around a natural spring that flows down in steps. The garden has three sections with a water channel, waterfall, and fountains. The spring begins at the top, marked by a small two-story Kashmiri house. The water then flows down, forming pools and fountains. Stairs allow visitors to walk up and see where the spring originates. We even got to drink the fresh spring water, which is believed to have health benefits. It is a lovely place to see in Kashmir. It was built by the Mughal Emperor Jahangir for his wife, Nur Jahan, in the 17th century. The garden is renowned for its stunning layout, intricate water channels, and vibrant flowerbeds. The design of Shalimar Bagh is based on the Persian Charbagh style, which symbolizes the four flowing rivers of paradise. The garden is divided into three terraces, each representing a different purpose: the first terrace is for public gatherings, the second for the royal family, and the third for the emperor and his court. One of the most striking features of Shalimar Bagh is the central canal, which runs through the garden and is lined with polished stones that shimmer in the sunlight. The garden is also adorned with beautiful pavilions, fountains, and meticulously manicured lawns. Visitors to Shalimar Bagh can enjoy a peaceful stroll amidst the lush greenery, listen to the soothing sound of water flowing through the channels, and marvel at the exquisite craftsmanship of the Mughal era. The garden's serene ambiance and historical significance make it a popular tourist attraction and a must-visit destination for those exploring the rich cultural heritage of Kashmir.Mustafa S ‚Äî Google reviewA nice place to visit after the 20th marchTundup T ‚Äî Google reviewOne of the most beautiful gardens in Kashmir. Situated along the scenic Boulevard Road near Nishat Ghat, this beautifully maintained Mughal garden offers an expansive and serene setting for visitors. The garden is terraced across three levels, with each level offering a unique perspective of the surrounding landscape. A moderate walk to the top rewards visitors with stunning panoramic views of the iconic Dal Lake‚Äîa truly picturesque sight. One of the standout features of the garden is the stream that flows gracefully through its center. This natural watercourse is said to be fed by the melting snow of the Himalayas, adding both charm and a refreshing ambiance to the setting. Visitor Tips: Allocate at least 1 to 2 hours to fully explore and appreciate the garden. Carry a water bottle and an umbrella, as sudden rain showers are common in the region. Reaching the upper levels of the garden may be challenging for young children or elderly visitors due to the incline. If you plan to sit and relax, consider bringing a waterproof mat, as the grass often remains damp from recent rainfall. It is a really beautiful garden on the east side of Dal Lake. It is the second biggest garden in Kashmir, after Shalimar Bagh. The garden has twelve terraces rising gently from the Dal Lake towards the Zabaran Mountains. A stream of water runs through the middle, with fountains and small waterfalls. This makes the garden look and feel very peaceful. From the garden, you get amazing views of Dal Lake and the snowy mountains behind it. There are tall Chinar and Cypress trees all around, and lots of colorful flowers. It is a very pretty and happy place. Tourists love to take lots of pictures here with their family and friends. Kids of all ages enjoy it too. They play, run around, and even splash in the water channel. When we visited in May 2024, there were many tourists having a good time in the garden. You need to buy a ticket to enter the garden. There is parking available inside and also along the street. It is good to check with the garden authorities or recent visitors beforehand to understand wheelchair accessibility. Here's a breakdown of what makes it so special: What to Expect & Experience: * Unique Cultural Insight: It's a living testament to Kashmiri culture and the traditional way of life on Dal Lake. You'll see local farmers and vendors conducting their wholesale business from their Shikara boats. * Vibrant and Bustling Atmosphere: Despite starting early, the market is a hub of activity. Boats laden with fresh vegetables (tomatoes, cucumbers, water chestnuts, lotus stems, etc.), fruits, and even flowers create a colorful spectacle against the serene backdrop of the lake. * Photographer's Paradise: The morning light, the colorful boats, the reflections on the still water, and the friendly interactions between vendors and buyers make for incredible photography opportunities. Many reviews highlight this as a prime reason to visit. * Authentic Interactions: While it's becoming a tourist attraction, it's primarily a local wholesale market. You'll witness friendly haggling and a strong community spirit among the traders. Some vendors also cater to tourists, selling saffron, cookies, and handicrafts. * Peaceful Shikara Ride: The journey to the market itself is an experience. You'll glide through the tranquil waters, passing by houseboats and local residences, offering a glimpse into the daily life of the lake dwellers. Best Time to Visit: * Early Morning is Crucial: The market starts very early, typically between 4:00 AM and 5:00 AM, and is largely over by 7:00 AM. To witness the full hustle and bustle, arriving before sunrise is essential. * Peak Seasons: The months of March to October are generally considered the best time to visit Dal Lake and the floating market, as the weather is pleasant. Summer (April to November) offers warm weather and mild temperatures, making the early morning ride comfortable * Dress Appropriately: While not explicitly mentioned for the market itself, it's generally good to carry a scarf and warm clothes, especially in the early morning, as Dal Lake can be windy. * Limited Facilities: As it's a floating market, expect limited facilities like restrooms. * Observe and Absorb: While you can buy items, a significant part of the experience is simply observing the unique local life and the vibrant exchange. The Dal Lake Floating Vegetable Market is a truly memorable and worthwhile experience. It offers a unique cultural immersion, stunning photographic opportunities, and a glimpse into a traditional way of life that is fast disappearing.Syed Q ‚Äî Google reviewThe amazing FLOATING VEGETABLE AND FLOWERS MARKET in Dal Lake, Srinagar Kashmir Srinagar's Dal Lake is famous the world over for its scenic location, for its Shikaras (boats) that float on it and for the promotion of aqua sports like water skiing. The Dal Lake is also famous for its 'floating vegetable market', the only one of its kind in India and only the second in the world, the other being the rowing shops along the backwaters of the Mekong Delta in Vietnam. Floating vegetable vendors are a prime tourist attraction in the Kashmir Valley, and this is reflected in the sales and annual turnover, estimated to be in the range of Rs. 35 crores. There are no permanent shops on the lake. The floating market first attracted international attention in 1960, when a Japanese photographer featured it in a tourist guide that was published out of Japan. Around 10,000 kanals (around 1,250 acres) of land along the Dal Lake is being used for the cultivation of vegetables, "This is a very old market where the sale and the purchase of vegetables take place between 5 am. and to 7 am. everyday. Most of the vegetables are grown on the lakeside and retrieved from the lake before being sold in just 2 hours. Any vegetables left over are taken to street markets. This market is famous. Many tourists come here just to take photographs of it. Dal Lake is home to vast stretches of lotus plant. Lotus flowers not only balance the wetland ecosystem, but also lend a special kind of beauty to the lake.Bilal P ‚Äî Google reviewAmazing place in the middle of Dal lake where you can see local vendors doing business for fresh organic vegetables. I loved my stay there! The Sabji Bazaar (meaning vegetable market) is the prime fascination for tourists in the valleys of Kashmir. It is an unorganized market where individual sellers gather in the center of the lake at the break of day and wrap up just as the sunlight touches the water.This market doesn't encourage selective or partial selling of items; it focuses instead on selling wholesale. The items for sale include tomatoes, carrots, turnips, leafy vegetables, and the famous nadru (lotus roots, a delicacy in the Kashmir Valley), all sown in the rich ecosystem of this wetland. The popular Kashmir flowers are also produced and sold in this market.Ansars P ‚Äî Google reviewA unique experience. We were surprised to see very few tourists. This Mughal-era garden is renowned for its lush greenery, vibrant flower beds, and the majestic Chinar trees that provide ample shade and enhance the garden's charm, especially during the autumn season when their leaves turn golden and red . üåø Highlights of Harwan Garden Natural Beauty: The garden features well-maintained lawns, colorful flower beds, and a canal that adds to its scenic allure. The presence of numerous Chinar trees makes it particularly attractive in October when the foliage displays brilliant hues . Peaceful Ambiance: Unlike some of the more crowded gardens in Srinagar, Harwan Garden offers a peaceful environment, making it an ideal spot for picnics, leisurely walks, and relaxation . Gateway to Adventures: Harwan Garden serves as the starting point for treks to Mahadev Mountain and is also the gateway to Dachigam National Park, providing opportunities for nature walks and wildlife exploration . üó£Ô∏è Visitor Reviews Visitors have praised the garden for its cleanliness, well-aligned concrete pathways, and the overall serene atmosphere. The arched gates adorned with climbing roses add to the garden's aesthetic appeal . Many travelers consider Harwan Garden a hidden gem in Srinagar, appreciating its tranquility and natural beauty. One reviewer mentioned, "Harwan Gardens are the best in Srinagar which is not crowded but an excellent one" . üìå Practical Information Location: Harwan, Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir, India. Entry Fee: As of the latest information, the entry fee is generally ‚Çπ20 per person for Indian visitors and ‚Çπ100 per person for foreign tourists . Best Time to Visit: The garden is most vibrant during the spring and summer months when the flowers are in full bloom. Autumn is also a great time to visit to witness the Chinar trees' colorful foliage . Facilities: While the garden offers a natural and serene environment, amenities such as food outlets and washrooms may not be available on-site. Visitors are advised to carry their own snacks and essentials . üìç Nearby Attractions Chandpora Harwan River: A beautiful and quiet spot ideal for relaxation, featuring a stream with fresh water directly from Mount Mahadev. Spanning 9 km, this national park was named after the renowned ornithologist Salim Ali to honor his contributions to bird conservation. The park serves as a vital habitat for various endangered species, including leopards and the majestic Kashmiri stag, alongside an impressive array of birds like kingfishers and swamp francolins.Salim ali national park is located in srinagar. It was Notified in 1986,After This park was converted in Royal spring golf course, srinagar between 1998 to 2001 By Farooq Abdullah. It was home to the Hangul, Himalayan serow and Himalayan Black bear. Hence, It is one of the Best bird centuaries in India.Suhail B ‚Äî Google reviewThat's not the correct location of Salim Ali national park also called City National Park. It was located where Royal Springs Golf Club stands now.Syed J ‚Äî Google reviewSalim Ali National Park or City Forest National Park is a national park located in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir, India.[citation needed] It covered an area of 9.07 km2.[1] Notified in 1986, the name of the park commemorated the Indian ornithologist Salim Ali.[2][3] The park was converted into the Royal Springs Golf Course, Srinagar between 1998 and 2001 by Farooq Abdullah, the then Chief Minister of Jammu & Kashmir.[2][4] His interest in Golf is very well known and encouraged him for the Golf course project next to Ecologically fragile Dal Lake. The park featured a wildlife species such as the hangul, musk deer, Himalayan black bear, leopard, Himalayan serow and 70 species of birds, including the paradise flycatcher, Himalayan monal, and Himalayan snowcock.Hitesh D ‚Äî Google reviewIt's near centur hotel, alongside the dal lake.Hamid M ‚Äî Google reviewSuperHashim M ‚Äî Google reviewGood parkExplore M ‚Äî Google reviewVery beautifulHarkirat S ‚Äî Google reviewNice pictureNikhil S ‚Äî Google review3RJ3+9JR, Shaheed Gunj, Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir 190001‚Ä¢Tips and more reviews for Salim Ali National ParkI'll never travel to Srinagar without this trip planner againStart planningLearn moreI will never travel to Srinagar without this app againAvailable on the App StoreDownload now16Shikara Ride Ghat No.1Save4.4(30)‚Ä¢Mentioned on¬†2 lists¬†Amusement park rideShikara Ride Ghat No.1 is a popular attraction located 4 km from Srinagar's city center. This magnificent floral expanse, recognized as Asia's largest tulip garden, draws visitors from across the globe, eager to witness its breathtaking panorama of colors . The garden transforms the landscape into a vibrant tapestry, a visual symphony that unfolds against the majestic backdrop of the Himalayan range. This report aims to provide a comprehensive overview of this iconic destination, exploring its identity and location, the key attractions it holds, its rich history and significance, and the optimal time to experience its ephemeral beauty. The idea for the Indira Gandhi Memorial Tulip Garden originated in 2006-07 with the aim of boosting tourism in the Kashmir Valley. It was established in 2007 and opened the following year. Interestingly, the garden was inspired by Indira Gandhi's desire to see tulips during a visit in 1976, and it was initially planted with 50,000 bulbs from the Netherlands This garden holds the distinction of being Asia's largest tulip garden, covering a substantial area. It plays a vital role in promoting both floriculture and tourism in the Kashmir region, attracting a large number of visitors each year. It also supports local research and development in floriculture and hosts the annual Tulip Festival, which celebrates Kashmiri culture alongside the stunning flowers.Wasim B ‚Äî Google reviewThe tulip garden was a breathtaking experience‚Äîvibrant rows of colorful tulips stretching as far as the eye could see. Spread over 30 hectares at the foothills of the Zabarwan Range, and overlooking the iconic Dal Lake, this garden is the largest tulip garden in Asia. Every year, during the spring season from late March to mid-April, the garden bursts into a mesmerizing display of color as more than 1.5 million tulips bloom across the terraces. With over 60 varieties of tulips in all shades imaginable ‚Äì red, yellow, pink, white, orange, and purple ‚Äì the sight is nothing short of magical. Established in 2007, the garden was created to promote floriculture and tourism in the valley. Since then, it has become a must-visit destination, especially during the annual Tulip Festival, which features cultural performances, Kashmiri handicrafts, local cuisine, and folk music. Apart from tulips, the garden also features other flowers like hyacinths, daffodils, muscari, and ranunculi that enhance the beauty of the landscape.Chandan S ‚Äî Google reviewWell maintained garden. And in between people start disturbing you .Saubhagya V ‚Äî Google reviewJhelum View Park is a popular tourist destination in Srinagar, the summer capital of the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir. As the name suggests, the park offers stunning views of the Jhelum River, which flows through the heart of the city. Located in the Rajbagh area of Srinagar, Jhelum View Park is a small but well-maintained park that is popular with locals and tourists alike. The park features well-manicured gardens, walking paths, and seating areas, as well as several small water features and fountains. Visitors to the park can relax and enjoy the peaceful surroundings while taking in the beautiful views of the Jhelum River and the surrounding mountains. In addition to its natural beauty, Jhelum View Park is also home to several important monuments and landmarks. The park features a large statue of Maharaja Hari Singh, who was the last ruler of the princely state of Jammu and Kashmir before it acceded to India. The park also houses a small museum dedicated to the history and culture of Jammu and Kashmir, which features exhibits on the region's art, crafts, and traditions. Overall, Jhelum View Park is a beautiful and peaceful oasis in the heart of Srinagar, and is a must-visit destination for anyone traveling to the city.Moumin D ‚Äî Google review3R9H+JMH, Abdullah Bridge, Rajbagh, Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir 190001‚Ä¢Tips and more reviews for River View Park27Zabarwan Range Trekking AreaSave4.5(18)‚Ä¢Mentioned on¬†1 list¬†Can somebody please tell me how long is this trek ,and is it safe in winters aren't there risk of animals at this time of the year?Wasim A ‚Äî Google reviewSuch a nice place to enjoy the panoramic view of Dal. It is renowned as the last refuge of the endangered Kashmir stag and has been a protected area since 1910. The park boasts diverse wildlife including musk deer, langurs, and black bears. Visitors can partake in thrilling activities such as Jeep safaris, river rafting, trekking to picturesque lakes, and more.Dachigam National Park, located near Srinagar in Kashmir, is a peaceful escape into nature. Famous for being home to the endangered Hangul deer, the park is a haven for wildlife enthusiasts. It boasts stunning landscapes, from dense forests to snow-covered peaks, offering beautiful views year-round. The park‚Äôs tranquil atmosphere makes it perfect for nature lovers and photographers alike. While it faces some conservation challenges, it remains a must-visit destination for those looking to experience the raw beauty of Kashmir.Md ( ‚Äî Google reviewWe visited the national park and unfortunately the park was closed for public due to a VIP visitor. Established during the reign of Emperor Jahangir in the early 17th century, it remains one of the finest examples of Mughal landscaping, combining natural beauty with architectural grandeur.Chenab T ‚Äî Google reviewKashmir Hill Gardens ACHABAL GARDENS- SRINAGAR Achabal Gardens, also referred as ‚Äòthe places of the princess‚Äô, is a small Mughal Garden located in Achabal, a town in Anantnag district of Kashmir valley. Lies at a distance of 58 km south of Srinagar, this garden is considered as one of the best Mughal Garden in India. It is believed to be built by Mughal Empress Nur Jahan, wife of Emperor Jahangir. Later, the garden was rebuilt on smaller scale by Dogra King Gulab Singh. The most attractive feature of the garden is that it is watered by one of the sacred mountain spring of the neighboring hill. The fountains in water springs of the garden represent a romantic history of the ancient era. Resting at a foot of a Himalayan hill, Achabal Gardens covers an area of 6.20 hectares.BHAT I ‚Äî Google reviewa splendous and lavish garden filled with a mesmerizing cradle of flowers, which scatter their scent and thrill the visitor with romantic essence.
